posted_at.relative: 5 days ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
India‚Äôs venture ecosystem is maturing fast, yet one pattern is becoming harder to ignore. The gap between companies that scale into category leaders and the broader pool of VC backed startups is widening.

Globally, data shows that unicorns command post money valuations anywhere from 3x to 10x higher than closely matched peers. This premium emerges as early as the seed stage and continues across every round in the lifecycle.

In India, the trend points in the same direction even if the numbers are less granular. We now have more than 100 unicorns with a combined valuation above US 360 billion. Their scale and momentum place them in a different league from the average startup raising venture capital.

Something else is shifting. The time it takes to reach unicorn status has doubled. In 2024, the average timeline stretched to about 11 years, compared to roughly 5.5 years just a year earlier. This tells us that the companies breaking through today are doing so with far more resilience, clarity and durability built into their model.

We also know the broader funding environment in India has tightened. Deal volumes and average round sizes dropped meaningfully in 2023, making outperformance even harder to achieve.

Put together, the message is clear. Becoming a VC backed company in India is no longer the differentiator. Becoming an outlier is.

The next decade in Indian venture will belong to the companies that choose to play at that level from day one.


#India #Investing #VC #Future

text:
Every strong business has an emerging challenger, even if you cannot see them yet.

Success often brings comfort. Comfort creates blind spots. That is usually when disruption enters quietly.

India has seen this play out up close. The taxi market had operated the same way for years. Fragmented, offline, resistant to change. Uber arrived with a simple idea and reshaped consumer behaviour across the country. The incumbents were larger and more established. Uber imagined a different future and moved before anyone else realised what was shifting.

The pattern is familiar. Disruption rarely begins with size. It begins with someone willing to question the assumptions everyone else accepts.

If there is a product, service or model that could challenge your business, someone is already exploring it. The smarter move is to build that version of your company from within before it comes from outside.

Momentum favours the ones who act early.

Founders often ask what truly impresses an investor. The answer is simpler than people think. Deep understanding.

If you know the full history of your space, you signal something rare. You show respect for the craft. You show that you have taken the time to study what worked, what failed and why the market looks the way it does today.

Every sector has a trail of earlier attempts. Some were ahead of their time. Some collapsed under the wrong model. Some were limited by technology that has only now matured. When a founder can explain these patterns with clarity, it immediately changes the conversation.

Investors pay attention to that level of awareness. It shows discipline. It shows judgment. It shows that you are building with intelligence rather than ego.
The fastest way to lose a room is to pretend history does not matter. Saying you are better than everyone who tried before you is not confidence. It signals a lack of curiosity.

The founders who study their space deeply always stand out. They build sharper products. They ask better questions. They understand timing. They respect the complexity of the market they want to change.

text:
The real challenge with change lies in staying with it.

After a Vipassana meditation retreat, I returned with a clear mind and deeper awareness. Mornings felt calmer, conversations felt more intentional, and each day carried a quiet sense of balance. For a while, that feeling stayed.

Then the pace of work, travel, and decision-making took over. That calm began to fade into the background.

It taught me something important. Change is not a single moment. It is a daily practice. The spark begins the journey, but structure helps it last.

Here are five ideas that have helped me sustain it over time.

1. Let it shape who you are.
When a practice becomes part of your identity, it stays. Mindfulness stopped being something I did. It became a way of being in how I lead, think, and respond.

2. Design for it.
Habits thrive when the environment makes them easy. Small cues like starting the morning in silence, keeping time away from screens, or pausing between meetings make a big difference.

3. Build accountability.
Sharing goals and progress with people who value similar growth helps you stay consistent. Growth feels lighter when it is shared.

4. Accept the rhythm of life.
Disruptions are inevitable. The key is to return quickly without guilt or frustration. The return matters more than the slip.

5. Reflect often.
A few quiet minutes each week to notice what worked and what did not can reset your focus and direction.

Change that lasts is rarely dramatic. It grows through repetition, awareness, and small steady choices that align with who you want to become.



#life #inspiration #growth #mindset #gratitude

Investor conversations can often sound like cocktail chatter, filled with opinions, predictions, and urgency. Market noise creates momentum, and momentum can easily be mistaken for insight.

Over time, I have learnt to pause and ask one question before every decision. What evidence have we earned, and what are we assuming. That single distinction separates clarity from consensus.

In early-stage investing, stories are easy to find. The real edge lies in process. Speak to customers, understand their patterns, and listen to what they value. Study the P and L until the numbers reveal where the business truly stands. Test the distribution logic until it works under pressure. Only then does conviction hold weight.

Founders who follow this approach build companies that endure. Investors who practise it make decisions they can trust through every market cycle.

Hype fades quickly. Discipline lasts longer and compounds quietly.

text:
India‚Äôs Playbook is Different.

The Western playbook rarely fits India. Our markets move to a different rhythm. Retail is fragmented, cultures shift every few kilometres, and buying behaviour changes with seasons, festivals, and even weather patterns.

Founders who succeed here understand these nuances early. They adapt formats, pricing, and distribution to local realities. They design SKUs that fit quick commerce baskets. They build loyalty through cultural rituals that matter to their audience. They empower field teams whose relationships and reputation drive trust in smaller towns.

India rewards founders who respect complexity. When strategy aligns with cultural truth, customer acquisition costs fall, retention improves, and working capital begins to breathe.

Every quarter, I ask one question. 

What have we done that makes our distribution harder to copy. The answer to that shapes long-term advantage.


#India #VentureCapital #ConsumerBrands #Entrepreneurship #Distribution #Leadership #Growth

Brand is Affinity, not Awareness

Awareness can be created through campaigns. Affinity must be earned through experience.

Every consumer brand starts with visibility, but the real journey begins after the first purchase. Repeat purchase is the true brand score. It reflects trust, habit, and emotional connection.

In a market like India, building affinity is about consistency in small details. The flavour that never disappoints. The packaging that feels familiar in a crowded shelf. The service that solves a problem quickly without friction. These are the quiet cues that make a brand part of a customer‚Äôs life.

When we evaluate consumer companies, we look for signals of this emotional durability. High retention rates, repeat purchases, and community-led growth all point to affinity. They show that the brand has moved from being a product to becoming a preference.

Great brands win twice. 

First in the market, then in the mind. 



#Brand #ConsumerInsights #VentureCapital #Entrepreneurship #CustomerExperience #Leadership

text:
Why second-time founders move differently.

When I meet second-time founders in India, there is one consistent difference. They are ruthless about saying no.

First-time founders try to do it all. Launch in multiple cities at once. Chase every distribution partnership. Hire for functions they do not need yet.

Second-time founders cut faster. They know distraction is more dangerous than competition. One retail pilot at a time. One core SKU before the catalogue expands. They do not confuse activity with progress.

This discipline is not cynicism. It is clarity born from scar tissue.

If you want to think like a second-time founder, start asking yourself: what will I regret spending time on a year from now?



#india #startups#growth#future #inspiration #success

author.headline: Founder & Managing Partner - Sharrp Ventures | Director - Marico Ltd. & Kaya Ltd. | Consumer Investor

text:
Founders often get caught up in being the first to launch. They race to grab headlines, close the initial round, and claim they are defining a category.

The truth is, being first rarely matters. What matters is being right.
India has shown this again and again.

The first e-commerce companies were not the ones that won. The first food delivery apps were not the ones that survived. The first D2C brands in categories like beauty or personal care are not the ones leading today.

Why? Because the market does not reward pioneers. It rewards those who execute, who adapt, who understand the customer deeply and scale patiently.

The founder who listens to their customer will always beat the founder who rushes to be early.

If you are spending more time worrying about competitors than about whether your customer is coming back, you are fighting the wrong battle.

First mover advantage is a headline. Real advantage comes from retention, insight, and execution.

So the question is not ‚ÄúCan I be the first?‚Äù
It is ‚ÄúCan I be the one that lasts?‚Äù


#india #entrepreneurship #strategy #future #success

The underrated moat: trust

In Indian consumer businesses, trust compounds faster than capital.

It is built quietly. Deliveries that reach smaller towns on time. Refunds that happen without a fight. Products that are consistent every single time.

We often celebrate blitzscaling. But the brands that become household names in India are the ones that customers feel safe to reorder from. Whether it is daily staples or premium experiences, trust drives repeat more than any campaign.

Trust does not show up on your P&L every quarter but it defines your P&L every decade.

Habits take time to form across geographies. Trust takes time to travel from metros to Tier 3 towns. Distribution takes time when every region has its own realities of logistics, payments, and culture.

The temptation is to declare success or failure too early. But I have seen businesses that looked flat in year two inflect in year five once trust and reach compounded. I have also seen others keep burning in hope when the customer signal was clearly missing.

The art is knowing which game you are in.

text:
The hidden cost of easy capital...

There is such a thing as money that comes too cheap, too soon.

In the last cycle, India saw D2C brands raise millions in seed and Series A rounds before unit economics were even tested. Teams grew faster than demand. Warehouses opened before product-market fit. Marketing spends ballooned while customer loyalty remained shallow.

Easy money makes everything look smooth. Until the cycle turns. Then habits built in abundance become liabilities in scarcity.

The founders who last are the ones who run the same way in both seasons. With focus. With frugality. With clarity.

Capital should not change your DNA. It should amplify it.

The danger of chasing categories, not customers.

Every quarter, I meet founders who proudly say, ‚ÄúWe are in the quick commerce space‚Äù or ‚ÄúWe are building for D2C beauty.‚Äù

The label sounds good in a pitch room. But my first question is always the same. Who is your customer?

Because categories are investor constructs. Customers do not think in categories. They think in problems.

In India, I have seen founders chase ‚Äúhot‚Äù tags like edtech or BNPL because capital was flowing, only to realise that retention and monetisation were weak once the initial hype wore off. 

At the same time, I have seen businesses solving everyday challenges like affordable protein or efficient distribution in Tier 2 towns not glamorous categories, but deeply needed. They scaled quietly, sustainably.

If your customer does not care about the category, then neither should you. Build for a person, not for a slide.

text:
The real signal in customer feedback.

Founders love hearing customer praise. It feels good. It motivates. But from an investor‚Äôs seat, praise is noise.

The real signal is in behaviour. Does the customer come back without discounts? Do they refer others? Do they use your product daily or weekly, even without nudges?

In consumer, intent and action are often misaligned. People say they love a product. Then they stop using it two weeks later.

As a founder, train yourself to look past words. Study the data. Study repeat rates, retention curves, usage frequency.

The harshest truth in consumer is this: customers vote with their time and wallet, not their compliments.

In the early days, most of it goes into product. Sitting with customers, building features, fixing bugs.

Seed-stage founders spending most of their week pitching investors instead of building. 

Series B founders still micromanaging features while culture slips through the cracks.

I see founders chase funding because ‚Äúit‚Äôs available‚Äù or because ‚Äúthe market is hot.‚Äù

The problem is, when you raise before you are ready, the capital creates expectations you cannot meet. Suddenly you need to grow faster, hire senior talent, expand into new markets. But your product is still figuring out retention.

This mismatch between capital and capability is what breaks early-stage companies. The pressure pushes founders to make short-term decisions, cut corners, and burn trust with investors.

Capital amplifies whatever is already there. If you are not yet ready, it amplifies chaos.

text:
In consumer startups, the real competition is not always the brand next to you on the shelf.

It is the clock.

The pace at which capital runs out. The time it takes to prove your thesis. The gap between launch and sustainable unit economics.

I meet founders who have product momentum but burn rates that leave them with less than a year to figure out retention, distribution efficiency, and pricing discipline. The product may be strong, but the runway is too short to navigate the learning curve.

The most resilient founders build with time in mind. They set up supply chains that can scale without breaking margins. They design marketing to grow repeat purchase before expanding reach. They ensure every quarter extends the business‚Äôs ability to survive market shocks.

A longer runway is not just safety. It is leverage. It lets you test, adapt, and capture market share with intention instead of desperation.

Before you chase the next growth spike, ask yourself one question. Will this choice buy me more time to get it right?

In the consumer space, time well used is often the ultimate competitive edge.


#india #startups #consumer #strategy #growth #success

author.headline: Founder & Managing Partner - Sharrp Ventures | Director - Marico Ltd. & Kaya Ltd. | Consumer Investor

posted_at.relative: 4 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
Valuation is not a milestone. It is a responsibility.

Too often, I see early-stage founders raise at valuations that feel good in the moment but set them up for trouble later.

You raise two million at a thirty million post. No revenue yet, but big plans. A year later, you hit three hundred thousand ARR. That is real progress. It is also not enough to justify a significant step-up.

Every round sets a benchmark. If your valuation outpaces your progress, future funding becomes harder, not easier. Investors begin to question the gap, and the pressure compounds at each stage.

At Sharrp, we see this pattern repeat. Founders focus on dilution, momentum, and optics. But very few pause to ask what numbers will justify my next round?

There is no magic in a high valuation unless you grow into it. Otherwise, you are spending more time trying to meet expectations than building your business.

The best founders do the opposite. They raise what they need. They price for where they are. They set targets they can hit within 18 to 24 months.

Ask yourself one thing before signing your next term sheet.
What will make the next round obvious?

If you do not have that answer, pause.

Building a company is hard. You need space to grow into your potential, not race against it.

Be realistic. Be intentional. That is how real value gets built.


#india #startups #entrepreneurship #mindset #valuation #investing

It was not loud. It was not performative. It was just real.

3. Builders get respect early. You do not need credentials or connections. If you are building something useful, you are already in the room

4. Thinking big is the norm. No one is trying to be incremental. Ambition is expected, not admired from a distance

5. The talent density is unmatched. Almost every conversation sharpens your thinking. The energy is contagious and makes you want to raise your game

Being in that kind of environment rewires how you approach your own work. It reminds you what is possible when people are focused, clear and generous with their thinking

Not all ecosystems are like this. But when you find one, pay attention. It will push you in the right way.

text:
I see a dozen pitch decks a day.

And the one slide that consistently misses the mark?

The TAM‚ÄìSAM‚ÄìSOM concentric circle masterpiece.

I skip past it every time.

Here‚Äôs why.

One, of course you‚Äôre going to say the market is massive. We all know India is a billion-plus population story. That‚Äôs not new.

Two, most founders map the market as it stands today. But the real opportunity is in where it is going, not where it‚Äôs been.

Three, the numbers are often stitched together from different sources and categories that don‚Äôt align with what you're actually building for.

And let‚Äôs be honest ‚Äî a lot of it is cherry-picked, top-down theory with no connection to the real customer or execution on the ground.

I have made the same mistake.

Here‚Äôs what works better.

Go bottom up.

Start with what you‚Äôve built. Who is using it. How often. What they are paying. What problem it solves.

Then walk us forward.

Who else this can reach. What categories it can stretch into. How habits and consumption are changing.

This gives us much more than a market estimate. It shows us how you think about GTM, retention, unit economics, brand, distribution, team, geography ‚Äî all in one frame.

A grounded slide with real customer behaviour and forward momentum beats theoretical billions every time.


#india #startups #investing #funding #growth #consumer #future

text:
What we are seeing globally today could easily be tomorrow‚Äôs India story.

Every month, we review consumer brands that are innovating across categories, not just in terms of ingredients but also in how they think about format, flavour, and function.

Here are 10 international brands that stood out recently. Each one holds a mirror to where Indian brands could go next:

1. Bask Suncare
Non-aerosol mineral sunscreen spray. Reapplication made simple.
üëâ India is still warming up to SPF sprays. But formats like this are exactly what will grow the category.

2. Cocojune Products
Coconut-based probiotic yoghurts. Clean, creamy, plant-forward.
üëâ Alt-dairy in India has potential if we stop chasing soy and start thinking taste-first.

3. Drumroll Snacks
High-protein, low-sugar donuts. Indulgence meets macros.
üëâ Snacking in India still leans clinical or cheat-day. This sits right in the middle.

4. Ella's Flats
Seed crackers used as snack bases. Crisp, whole, visually vibrant.
üëâ This is a packaging and positioning story waiting to happen in India‚Äôs urban centres.

5. Hero Bread
0‚Äì1 net carb bread with protein and fibre. Strong influencer play.
üëâ Indian health bread players can unlock bigger value through branding, not just claims.

6. NUFYX¬Æ 
Keto plant protein powders that feel like dessert. Organic, digestible, smooth.
üëâ Plant protein here is gaining traction, but taste is still an afterthought.

7. SAUZ
Fresh pasta sauces with bold ingredients. Focused on flavour, not fear.
üëâ Clean label in India is often too cautious. There is room for brands to lead with confidence.

8. STRANGE WATER
Sparkling coconut water. Same base, new behaviour.
üëâ This is one of the smartest repositioning moves I have seen. India‚Äôs coconut water brands can push this.

9. Visitor Beer*
Crisp non-alcoholic beer with branding that works at bars.
üëâ We are seeing early signs here, but there is a long way to go in taste and occasion mapping.

10. Whims Delights
Oat milk chocolate bites. Vegan, low-sugar, genuinely snackable.
üëâ No one is owning this space in India yet. Huge opportunity.

Each of these brands tells us something: the edge is no longer about ingredients. It is about how clearly you solve a real-world moment with joy, function, and relevance.

To Indian founders building in food, wellness, or skincare, there is white space waiting to be owned.


#India #Branding #Marketing #Packaging #Startups #Future #Trends

As I look back, a few quiet truths have stayed with me. They were not loud lessons. They came slowly, through experience, through stillness, and through choosing to pay attention.

1. Health is the foundation. Everything else is built on it. Without it, even the best plans fall apart. Prioritise it before you are forced to.

2. Time is your most valuable asset. If you give it away too freely, it disappears without return. Invest it with intention. Let it grow into something meaningful.

3. Friendships are among life‚Äôs most enduring gifts. The ones that stay without expectation, without performance, are rare. Nurture them with care.

4. Forgiveness is not about forgetting. It is about releasing the weight you were never meant to carry. Forgive early so you can move freely.

5. There is wisdom in walking away. Not every path deserves your presence. Knowing when to step back is strength, not failure.

Still learning. Still walking. Still open to where the road leads next.
Grateful for all the steps it has taken to reach here.

text:
Excellent advice from Jeff Bezos's last shareholder letter:

"In what ways does the world pull at you in an attempt to make you normal? 

How much work does it take to maintain your distinctiveness? 

To keep alive the things that make you special? 

We all know that distinctiveness and originality is valuable. We are all taught to "be yourself." 

What I'm really asking you to do is to embrace and be realistic about how much energy it takes to maintain that distinctiveness. 

The world wants you to be typical, in a thousand ways it pulls at you. Don't let it happen. 

You have to pay a price for your distinctiveness, and it's worth it. 

The fairy tale version of "be yourself" is that all the pain stops as soon as you allow your distinctiveness to shine. That version is misleading. Being yourself is worth it, but don't expect it to be easy or free. 

You'll have to put energy into it continuously. 

Be kind, be original, create more than you consume, and never, never, never, let the universe smooth you into your surroundings."



#Leadership #Inspiration #Mindset #Startups #Success

In the consumer space, early traction can feel like a green signal to go faster. More SKUs. More channels. More markets.

text:
I recently travelled to Japan with my family, and the experience left a mark. It gave me a window into a culture shaped by quiet strength, shared values, and deep-rooted discipline.

Here are a few things that stood out:

1. Respect is central. From how people greet each other to how they conduct conversations, there is a strong sense of mutual respect woven into daily life.

2. Attention to detail is a way of being. Whether it is the way food is plated or how a train platform is marked, everything is done with care and precision.

3. Time is honoured. Punctuality is non-negotiable. Being on time is seen as a sign of respect for others and for your own word.

4. Cleanliness is collective. Public spaces are spotless, not because of rules, but because people take personal ownership of shared environments.

5. Harmony guides behaviour. The focus is on community over individualism. Decisions are made with consideration for how they affect the whole.

There is a quiet power in this kind of culture. One that makes you pause, observe, and re-evaluate how we live and work. 

Coming back, I find myself asking - how can we bring some of this clarity, respect, and intentionality into the way we build, lead, and grow?


#culture #inspiration #travel #Japan

text:
Building a Brand in India? 

Consumer brands in India do not scale overnight. The companies that succeed are the ones that understand patience is part of the process.

Most founders overestimate how fast they can grow and underestimate how long it takes to build trust. Unlike tech startups that can scale through code, consumer brands need distribution, word-of-mouth, and a strong reputation.
Indian consumers have options. They will not commit to a brand unless they see long-term value. 

This means repeatable quality, customer experience, and consistent brand messaging over years, not just viral campaigns and deep discounting.

If you are building a brand, think about how it will sustain for decades, not just the next quarter.

The real competition is not other startups. It is time.

text:
Funding Winter or Reality Check?

Indian startups have spent the last few years chasing growth at all costs. Now, funding is harder to come by and everyone is talking about a funding winter.
The truth is, this is not a downturn. It is a reset.

Investors are no longer excited by high burn rates and flashy expansion plans. They want to see businesses that are disciplined, efficient, and built for sustainability. A startup that can survive without constant external capital is always in a stronger position.

Valuations are a reflection of fundamentals. When the focus shifts back to profitability, capital efficiency, and customer stickiness, the companies that have been built well will thrive.

The funding winter is only a problem for those who built without a plan.


#india #startups #funding #investing

text:
Ideas get attention. Execution builds companies.

The consumer brands that stand out today are not the ones with the most innovative concepts, but the ones that execute relentlessly. Markets shift, consumer behaviours evolve, and new competitors emerge overnight. The real test of a startup is how well it adapts and moves forward despite these challenges.

We look for founders who are not just problem-spotters but solution-builders. The ones who thrive under pressure, make decisions quickly, and keep momentum even when the odds are against them.

A great product is just the starting point. The ability to take that product to market, scale efficiently, and create lasting value is what separates brands that last from those that fade away.

How do you assess execution ability in your team?

posted_at.relative: 9 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
Pricing is not about cost‚Äîit is about perceived value.

Consumer brands win by balancing affordability and aspiration. A few questions every founder should ask before setting pricing:

- Who is my customer, and what do they expect to pay?
- What alternatives exist, and how does my price stack up?
- Does my pricing align with my brand positioning? Premium brands cannot be priced for mass, and vice versa.
- What is the psychological price threshold? Rs. 999 feels very different from Rs. 1001.

Pricing is strategy, not math. Get it wrong, and you lose margins or volume. Get it right, and you build long-term value.


#startups #strategy #pricing
